Note: Symptoms: One segmentation cluster slowed down due to activity from customer ace and others.

'templawebster' overloaded the Segmentation Service causing email and automation program processing delays for all customers and causing potentially false email campaign status displays (aborted) for the impacted campaigns
Increased web load on suite27 due to a surge in segmentation requests from one customer.
Contact lists still in use on wait nodes were deleted from automation programs causing contacts to be removed from those programs.
A sudden and extreme surge in API requests to the segmentation-service overloaded the suite30 webservers resulting in partial API call blocking.
some routing changes deployed for SeSe resulted in double consumption of request bodies leading to internal server errors.
Because of high load coming from Limango (~2.5 million segment requests in 1 hour) through Interactions there was a slowdown in Interactions because of Segmentation.
High db load transactional segmentation was affected on all environments (normally 5s went up to 5 minutes)
Segmentation service (SeSe) has unusually big numbers of redis keys. SeSe cluster breakdown.
Delays in segment runs (The issue is most likely related to the tool used for clustering in the segmentation service)
Suite 5 API calls are limited due to too many connections in the main database. SeSe was down so transactional segment executions were delayed during this time.
s5 API limited The issue was triggered by a large number of segmentation requests that flooded the s5 database with connections. (problematic endpoint: look up a contact in a segment)
suite10 down (Found a program that us a userlist with 2million entries)
Transactional segment requests are slower than usual (Root cause: This happened because we currently have 150000 queue items in the segmentation service.)
Slowdown in segmentation happened because a customer accidentally sent a large number of requests causing a DDoS-like effect.
Throughput degradation in Segmentation Akka cluster has got into an inconsistent state due to a not standard restart
